answers.answer: Bumping this up for others to post...............

I was diagnosed with Hashi's approx. 10 years ago when I was 20.  When we decided we were ready to have a baby (I was 26), we conceived in the first month of trying.  I was very worried that my thyroid would cause issues, but in my experience it did not.  Monitoring my levels was key so my OB and family dr. tested me more often.  My prescription had to be changed a little early in my pregnancy and immediately after I had my son, but all in all for me it was not a big deal at all.

question: Hi,I was recently diagnosed with likely hashimoto's, although my TSH is only 6.4 and my T3/T4 are in the normal range.I have had positive ANA antibodies in the past too, but no other health conditions (maybe just on the low end of pre-diabetes).Anyway, I'm extremely worried about my fertility now. I read that the most common reason for early menopause/premature ovarian failure is Hashimoto's. I can't understand why I have Hashi's at 28 - none of my family members have it.Should I try to conceive now? I'm so worried that I'll go through early menopause. This fear is ruining my life, and I don't want to go out or do anything.Please help.
title: Hashimoto's and fertility
